summary: A letter from defense attorney Gerald B. Lefcourt to a federal prosecutor, transmitting highlighted excerpts and full transcripts of witness interviews from the state investigation into Jeffrey Epstein. The letter argues the evidence shows no federal crime occurred and attempts to restrict the government's use of the draft transcripts. This document is a transcript of a videotaped interview, likely with a witness or victim, conducted by a detective as part of the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein. The interviewee describes being recruited to give massages to Epstein, the nature of the massages, financial arrangements, and their role in recruiting other young women, including a minor. This document contains draft transcripts of police interviews with multiple young women/victims regarding their experiences at Jeffrey Epstein's Palm Beach residence. The interviews detail recruitment by a friend, the promise of money for massages, and escalating sexual demands by Epstein, including requests for nudity and touching. The victims describe being minors (16-17 years old) at the time of the incidents.

persons.name: Gerald B. Lefcourt
persons.context: Attorney representing Jeffrey Epstein; author of the cover letter arguing against federal prosecution and providing witness interview transcripts.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Wealthy individual who pays for massages from young women, often with escalating sexual expectations. The interviewee describes his house, his rules for recruits, and his behavior during massages.

persons.name: Sheryl E. Reich
persons.context: Attorney at Gerald B. Lefcourt's law firm, listed on the letterhead.

persons.name: Renato C. Stabile
persons.context: Attorney at Gerald B. Lefcourt's law firm, listed on the letterhead.

persons.name: A. Friedman
persons.context: Attorney at Gerald B. Lefcourt's law firm, listed on the letterhead.

persons.name: Lilly Ann Sanchez
persons.context: Attorney copied on the letter; likely involved in the case.

persons.name: Detective
persons.context: Conducts the videotaped interview, asking detailed questions about the interviewee's interactions with Jeffrey Epstein and the recruitment of other girls.

persons.name: The Witness
persons.context: A young woman (aged 18-20 during events) who was recruited to give massages to Jeffrey Epstein, was paid $300, and later recruited other girls for him, including a 16-year-old.

persons.name: Detective 2
persons.context: Listed as a participant in the interview on October 11, 2005.

connections.description: Lefcourt is the defense attorney representing Epstein, as shown by the letter arguing his case and providing evidence.
Both are attorneys at the same law firm, as listed on the letterhead.
Sanchez is copied on the legal correspondence from Lefcourt, indicating professional involvement in the case.
The witness provided massages to Epstein, sometimes in her underwear, and he touched her inappropriately (hip, buttocks, under clothes). She was paid $300 per session.
The detective is formally interviewing the witness to gather information about Epstein's activities and her role in recruiting others.
The witness recruited other girls for Epstein, following his rule that they must know what to expect beforehand. She received more money for bringing girls.
Epstein paid the underage victim for massages and made sexual advances, including requests to remove clothing and touching.
A friend recruited the victim, arranged the visits to Epstein's house, explained the 'massage' setup, and was paid by Epstein for bringing the victim.
Epstein paid the friend hundreds of dollars to recruit and bring other girls to his house for massages.

events.title: Defense submits interview excerpts to prosecutor
events.description: Epstein's defense attorneys send highlighted excerpts and full transcripts of witness interviews to the Assistant U.S. Attorney, arguing against federal prosecution.

events.title: Witness interviews conducted
events.description: Multiple witness interviews were conducted by detectives, as indicated by the timestamps on the attached draft transcripts (e.g., 3/15/05).

events.title: Massage sessions at Epstein's house
events.description: The witness describes multiple visits to Epstein's Palm Beach house to give him massages. Sessions escalated from fully clothed to her being in bra and underwear, with Epstein touching her inappropriately.

events.title: Recruitment of a 16-year-old girl
events.description: The witness states she took a 16-year-old girl to Epstein's house about 8 months prior to the interview, and the girl knew what she was getting into.

events.title: Interview with law enforcement
events.description: A detective conducts a videotaped interview with the witness, discussing her experiences with Epstein and her recruitment of others.

events.title: Police Interview of Victim
events.description: A detective conducts a videotaped/taped interview with a young woman regarding her experiences with Jeffrey Epstein, focusing on details of massages, nudity, and sexual contact.

events.title: Victim's First Visit to Epstein's House
events.description: A victim describes being recruited by a friend and taken to Epstein's Palm Beach house for the first time for a paid massage, which involved requests to be topless.

events.title: Recruitment and Payment
events.description: A friend recruits another girl from school, telling her she can make $200 for a 45-minute massage at an 'old guy's' house, and threatens her to keep it secret.

locations: Epstein's house (described as massive, with a kitchen, stairs, second floor, pool, and a dedicated massage room)
keyFacts: Epstein's defense team provided the prosecution with draft transcripts of witness interviews from the state investigation, arguing the evidence shows no federal crime.

The defense letter categorically argues Epstein did not ask for or receive genital contact, sexual intercourse, seek out underage women, coerce anyone, and that women were apprised of what would happen.

The defense attempts to restrict the government's use of the draft transcripts, stating they are provided as a courtesy and are not usable for any purposes, and the government must agree not to use revisions against Epstein.

Attached interview excerpts contain denials from witnesses about specific sexual acts with Epstein, but also contain statements like 'the younger the better' attributed to Epstein and discussions of girls lying about their age.
The witness was 18-20 years old during her interactions with Jeffrey Epstein and was paid $300 for massage sessions.
Epstein had a rule that girls brought to his house must know what they were "getting into" beforehand, which involved sexual expectations beyond a massage.
The witness recruited other girls for Epstein, including a 16-year-old, and received more money for bringing them.
During massages, the witness was sometimes only in her underwear, and Epstein touched her hip, buttocks, and tried to touch her under her clothes.
The witness describes Epstein's behavior as not forcing her but trying to talk her into more, and he would stop if she said she was uncomfortable.
Multiple underage girls (aged 16-17 at the time) were recruited by a friend and paid by Jeffrey Epstein for 'massages' at his Palm Beach residence.
The recruitment process involved the friend being paid $300-$400 by Epstein for bringing new girls, and the victims being paid $200 per visit.
The massages involved escalating demands: initially described as just a massage, but with expectations to remove clothing (topless, then potentially more) and endure sexual touching.
Victims describe being scared, uncomfortable, and aware that the situation was not normal, with one stating she stopped going because Epstein 'kind of scared me.'
The police detective indicates he has interviewed 'a lot of girls' about similar experiences at Epstein's house, suggesting a pattern of behavior.
